subject: Cooking
title: Umami Cultures: East vs. West
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Umami Cultures: East vs. West.

hook.text: Asian cuisines have celebrated umami for centuries. Western cooking only recognized it in 2002. Why the gap?

buildup.text: Japanese, Chinese, and Korean cuisines built entire flavor systems around fermented umami-rich ingredients.

discovery.text: Western cuisine focused on the sweet-salty-sour-bitter framework, treating savory depth as secondary.

twist.text: Western cooks used umami all along â€” in aged cheese, tomato sauce, and Worcestershire â€” they just didn't name it.

climax.text: The recognition of umami receptors in 2002 finally gave Western science language for what Asia always knew.

punchline.text: The West didn't discover umami. It finally acknowledged it.
